PROF.
WAMPLER: Well,

the Cuba Studio last spring,
which was a level two studio,

the overview follows my
philosophy about architecture.

And that is that I don't
believe students should just be

at MIT inside these walls
designing for people around the

world.
I think the issue is

maintaining identities of
people, of cultures,

being sensitive to climate
conditions, architecture,

where we are,
where they, in this case,

may be working.
So the theory behind it is to

take my students to a place that
they don't know,

immerse them into that culture
as quickly as possible,

let them talk to the people,
let them move around the city,

let them absorb what there is
about that place so that when

they design, it was a design
project, they are coming from

the point of sensitivity to the
people and to the culture.

Not from some Western notion
about what architecture should

be or not from some intellectual
position, although that is

important, but they are coming
from understanding the site,

understanding the buildings,
the people, the culture,

the history.
So that is central to all my

work as an overview.
And the Cuba Studio is an

example of that.
I think the goals of this

studio, and also working with
Cuba are somewhat similar.

I go places where I am invited
and where the studio can help,

because MIT has incredible
researches.

And let's share them with the
rest of the world if we can.

So, actually,
the project in Cuba was one

that they wanted because they
want prototype about how to

develop areas.
In terms of what I want

students to get out of this,
I want them to make the most

beautiful buildings in the
world, but I want those

buildings to relate to the
people.

And so I am not just teaching
how to design buildings which,

of course, is part of the
studio, nor am I teaching just

that we should be making
beautiful building,

but we should be making the
best architecture we can make

and respond to the people's
needs.

Now, I am critical of our
profession because I think often

architects are what I call
technocrats.

They just kind of follow what
somebody tells them to do and

they are technicians.
My goal for the students is to

come away, of course,
with open doors into a new way

of looking at architecture.
There may never be a typical

week, but I will tell you the
ingredients that go into

teaching are a combination.
Today I am going to show some

of my own work,
so it is a combination of

lecturing and about work that I
have done.

And, more importantly,
how I have gotten to that work

not only to work.
It is a combination about

lectures of particular subjects.
Maybe materials or sunlight,

issues that I'm concerned
about.

It is an intense experience,
what we call desk-side crits

where you sit down with the
student and you look at their

work.
And it is kind of an

interesting process.
I have done it for years.

You quickly see what they are
doing.

They have sketched something or
they made a model and you have

to very quickly say what you
think about that.

We have what we call pinups
which are reviews.

In my case, they are quite
often, once a week where the

students put their work up and
we, as a class,

talk about it.
I encourage my studio class to

actually engage in the
discussion about the work.

And, in fact,
just last week I asked them to

trade models,
exchange models and talk about

each other's work to get them
out of their own way of

thinking.
And then there are periods of

just working in the studio.
And then full scale reviews

where I invite people in from
other faculty of the school or

other professions to give them
feedback.

I think in the studio teaching
it is important to get out of

the studio and go into what I
call the library of architecture

forum, everything that is around
us.

In all my studios,
the site is very important to

understand.
I tell them when I was in

school I used to go sleep on the
site for a weekend,

and I will cookout and so on,
so that I could get to know the

site as well as my own backyard.
And then I would come back and

announce to my professor that
the site was too beautiful to

build on.
And I am glad I am not one of

my students.
But anyway the point is to

absorb the site as much as you
can, absorb the outside.

So I think part of the studio,
or a big part of the studio is

getting out of here,
getting out of MIT.

Now, the other side of that is
that I bring people in who know

about, in this case,
Havana, Cuba to talk,

to give overviews.
I want my students to know as

many different views as they
can.

And then from that they make a
decision.

I think the teaching of a
studio and the teaching of

architects is the most important
thing we can do because I think

the architects are the only ones
that are going to be looking out

for the physical world.
And the physical world is in

bad shape.
And, in this generation,

it may disappear as we know it.
I think of architects as

caretakers of the physical
world.

I think we have to be
sensitive, much more sensitive

than we have been to cultures,
to the land,

to the forest,
to the water,

to everything,
materials.

We are more than technicians.
We are what I call creative

leaders.
And I think that is a new role

for us, and I think it is a very
important one that we take very
seriously.
